story.text: This talk is a culmination of about eight years of thinking about incidents and pages. My team runs api.newrelic.com. We have 40 externals and 13 data stores. We should be down all the time. Three years ago we got paged about five times a week. Now we get paged about once per month. Don't page me! How we limit pager noise at New Relic by Chuck Lauer Vose @ RailsConf 2022 [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNMQpkb7uvE youtube]

YOUTUBE uNMQpkb7uvE
Don't page me! How we limit pager noise at New Relic by Chuck Lauer Vose @ RailsConf 2022 [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNMQpkb7uvE youtube]
1. notifications received during an incident deserve retros.
2. default alert conditions ALWAYS require refinement.
If you have a pager noise problem, here is the map:
15% focus on fixing the alert condition as well as the incident
20% refine alert conditions to include more data
25% add heartbeat monitors for webapps, job systems, mail systems, etc.
35% add circuit breakers and bulkheads (Semian for Ruby projects). Implement dark deployment practices.
Don't page me! How we limit pager noise at New Relic by Chuck Lauer Vose @ RailsConf 2022 [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNMQpkb7uvE youtube]
